[{'id': 476, 'article_title': "Treatment of Kroomen in Her Majesty's Ships", 'full_section_title': "Treatment of Kroomen in Her Majesty's Ships", 'last_edit_date': '10-01-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-15', 'issue_date': '23_11_1864', 'content': "Sir,—You being our advocate, and through whom we have been able to bring our complaints before the good people and authorities of England, I beg to request a place in your paper for the following.

For some years past, say from since the Russian war, there have been various changes and amendments made in Her Majesty's Navy, all tending to the better accommodation and comfort of the seamen as well as officers, such as pay, &c.* (white men, we mean), but we have never seen anything to that effect concerning the blacks or Kroomen who are constantly employed therein.

Before going into other matters, we will ask one or two questions. Which have the strongest and best men, the merchantmen, or the men-of-war? In which of the two have the Kroomen the best treatment? Why, in the merchant service, and that is the reason latterly that the men-of-war ships cannot get such good men, as they used to do formerly.

In the first place, the Kroomen of merchant ships are well treated, better cared for; they have the hold to sleep in at night or the long boat covered over; or when laying in the rivers, the cask-house, so as to keep them from rain and dew at night, thereby preventing them in a great measure from getting sick. Whenever any extra work is done or the captain thinks they deserve it, there is an extra glass of grog for them, or a dash of a handkerchief or clout, and almost every one is sure of a Sunday clout every Sunday, be the captain ever so bad or stingy; and above all, they are not so kicked, cuffed, abused, and driven about like beasts by every one on board as in the Navy. The captain and mate are the persons they look to and from whom they get, through their headman, their orders; and from the headman they get their punishments, when they deserve it; and when the vessel is going home they are well paid, and, according to their deserts, get a corresponding number of presents and a good book.* But not so in the men-of-war, where in eight cases out of ten we, the blacks or Kroomen, seem to be entered on board as regular drudges and servants to any one, officers, men, or boys, to clean the dirt of almost every one, as well as do our own work about the ship.

We hardly dare open our mouths in remonstrance to even a sailor, for fear of worse punishment, for daring to give cheek to a white man. In most ships we have nowhere either to sleep or rest ourselves except the open deck, night or day, whether rain or sun; we dare not show our faces below decks except upon duty, or we stand the chance of being driven on deck like a mangy dog; and when we get sick, which often happens, through exposure to rain and by laying about the decks, we are scarcely ever looked after, nor given shelter to. We have known some of our countrymen with consumption, and very often fever, who had no other shelter from the weather but his blanket drawn over him, or the privy, which he is very often turned out of; and to make a long story short, we are badly paid."}, {'id': 476, 'article_title': "Treatment of Kroomen in Her Majesty's Ships", 'full_section_title': "Treatment of Kroomen in Her Majesty's Ships", 'last_edit_date': '10-01-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-15', 'issue_date': '23_11_1864', 'content': 'We get the same—11. 8s.—as we had fourteen years ago, out of which we have to pay for our soap to keep ourselves clean, tobacco, duck, flannel, serge, and such other articles as we are obliged to take, to be of the same uniform as the white men.

We have all the dirtiest and hardest work to do out here, besides abuse and hard usage to put up with, and nothing to gain. We are taught nothing but to scrub decks, haul on ropes, clean brass work, scrape masts, clean the ship's sides, and privies, carry coal bags and such like—in fact, we are more like slaves (and on board English men-of-war too) than free men. Well, for all this what future hope have we? We are not allowed good conduct pay; we nor our families are allowed any pension if we serve so long or anything happens to us; besides other little allowances that are allowed to white men in the British Navy. Now on board merchant ships we learn something about sailoring, for we are taught not with rope's-end, as on board men-of-war. There are men who can make any splice or almost any knot, steer, reef, take a long boat from land to land, &c., &c.

How many will there be found in men-of-war vessels to do those things? Not many. Why? Not that they are not capable of doing or learning to do so, or that many of us have not the wish to learn, but merely because we have no encouragement, no future advantage to hope for.

If the authorities of the British Navy wish to have a standing lot of good smart blackmen or Krooboys in their men-of-war, let them direct their attention to our complaints, and, if possible, give us such treatment, attention, &c., as men on board ships of a free and liberal nation ought to have, and which is not the case now.

When we speak of men-of-war, we except the Rattlesnake, for on board her we must acknowledge that the blacks or Kroomen get every privilege. The only thing they have to complain of there is the pay, which we know it, is not in the power of the good Commodore to alter. We beg you will excuse us for the length of our letter, and also request that you will make such corrections as are necessary, so as to convey the substance of our communication.—We are, your obedient servants, KROOMEN.

* "Testimonial" we suppose is meant by this.—Ed. A. T.'}, {'id': 5917, 'article_title': 'THE POSITION OF THE NEGRO IN AMERICA', 'full_section_title': 'THE POSITION OF THE NEGRO IN AMERICA', 'last_edit_date': '10-22-1889', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_11_1889#article-2', 'issue_date': '04_11_1889', 'content': "Finally, it was not until Monday last that Fred Douglass, the United States Minister Plenipotentiary to the Republic of Hayti, was able to start for his post on board of the frigate Kearsarge, after no fewer than three captains of the Government Navy had been suspended from duty and deprived of their commands in consequence of their refusal to receive a man of the Envoy's colour and race on terms of equality at their table or as passenger on board their ships. As for the ordinary mail steamers to the West Indies, it was hopeless to attempt to send the Minister to Hayti on board any of them. For so strict are their rules and regulations on the subject of the colour line that they would only have been able to give deck passages to his Excellency and his party.

The incidents above related are but mere drops of water in the ocean of similar cases which could be adduced in support of the assertion that at no time has the antipathy and animosity of the white race in America towards the black brother been so violent and so bitter as at present; and whereas the spirit of intolerance with regard to the negro was formerly confined to the South, it has now spread to the North, the East, the West—in fact over the entire continent."}]

[{'document_title': 'Ill-treatment of Krooboys on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—The steamship Roquelle arrived at this port on the afternoon of Tuesday, the 11th inst., and, as usual, several Krooboys went on board to ship for the Leeward. I, fortunately, went on board in my boat. Night had come on, and the officer, after selecting what boys he wanted, flogged the others overboard with a rope's end and iron belaying pins. I saw more than a dozen boys struggling in the water. My boat picked up two of them, and the rest, not knowing how to swim, were evidently drowned, for they have not been seen since. Neither myself nor my boatmen saw them any more, except the two we picked up. The native canoes had all gone on shore, so that my boat was the only craft alongside the steamer. The Krooboys are the most useful of the Africans on board ships in the oil rivers and other trading stations on the Coast, and yet they are the most ill-used by the officers of these steamers, though they themselves cannot do without them.

I have reported the matter officially to our Governor here, who has promised to report the same to our Secretary of State at Monrovia, the head-quarters, who, I hope, will open a correspondence with the Agent of the British and African Steam Navigation Company.—I am Sir, your obedient servant,", 'last_edit_date': '1875-05-17', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1875#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.615, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sna, a Krooman, v. the African Steamship Company', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In order that any further observation we may have to make upon this case, and the serious question involved by the course taken by the African Royal Mail Steamship Company, we think it right again to state that this poor Krooman, Sna, lost one of his legs whilst working as a labourer on board of one of the Company's steamers on the West Coast of Africa. He applied to the Directors to make him a compensation, which they refused, and he brought an action against them in the Supreme Court at Sierra Leone to recover damages for the injury; but the Company—although the writ was served upon their agent there—did not appear to the action. Mr. Rainy (Sna's counsel) applied to the Court for leave to proceed in the case; but the Judges held that as the law stood they had no power to grant the application, and the Chief Justice intimated that Mr. Rainy should apply to the Legislature to enact a law upon the subject.

The Sierra Leone Interpreter contains the following on this important subject: "We are glad to learn by advices received from England that the untenable and anomalous position taken up by the African Steamship Company is likely to undergo the severe test of public opinion. We hardly thought that such a violation of every principle both of constitutional and common law could have long passed unnoticed, and the only wonder is that the combined and indignant voices of this country have not long since repudiated so monstrous an assumption and usurpation. In the worst and most unconstitutional days which darkened the history of England and her colonies we in vain seek a parallel for the conduct of this despotic company.', 'last_edit_date': '1868-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1868#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.624, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A Military Officer Punished', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Dated as above, a letter has come to us, which, although we cannot publish it entire, is very important, as showing that the class of British military officers which has from time to time brought so much disgrace on the service has still its representatives on the West Coast of Africa. We deeply regret that such events as those depicted by our informant should occur, and also that it should be necessary for us to omit the name of the individual who so grossly misconducted himself on the occasion alluded to. We now proceed to give as nearly as possible the contents of the letter:—

"—— (a military officer) arrived here on the 2nd July last in the steamship Volta, which steamer brought also his Excellency Dr. Rowe and some other military officers. These all accompanied his Excellency on shore to see him sworn in at Government House. As is customary on such occasions, the Moselle and brandy circulated freely among the favoured guests. The officers returned on board, and I suppose —— must have been under alcoholic influence, or he would not have shown such selfish and brutal passion to the poor boatmen, who only asked to be compensated for taking him on board, or have assaulted and abused the merchant's clerks who went to discharge their employers' cargo brought out by the steamer. Listen to this officer of Her Majesty Queen Victoria: 'I do not care a —— about black niggers, and I am determined to kill one before I am satisfied.' —— also assaulted the policeman and Customs officers who were on duty on board the Volta, as is customary; and we are told that the authorities declined to grant any redress to the poor Customs' House officers. Is it not wrong that there should be no redress for persons thus unwarrantably treated? Fortunately, however, his Excellency sent for the military officers to come on shore again, and we saw —— and other officers coming on shore in civilian's dress, when our people took the matter into their own hands, and as soon as —— landed from the boat, the black niggers fell upon him and gave him such blows that he fell flat on the beach. When we saw him soon afterwards, he was, with his pocket-handkerchief on his bleeding nose, on his way to Government House. I am sure —— will remember Bathurst, River Gambia, and, in particular, the black niggers' blows. We do not think that the steamer's officers should have allowed such brutal treatment of clerks who went for their employers' cargo on board, but we suppose they did not dare to interfere with a Queen's officer."', 'last_edit_date': '1875-07-19', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1875#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AGAINST MILITARY MAGISTRATES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—I believe that everyone who has the honour of being a British subject, is justly entitled to the privilege and protection which British laws afford. Prejudice of colour, with an inadequate or almost no knowledge of law, exist to such an extreme on the West Coast of Africa, that oftentimes in our courts of law we sue entirely in vain for the impartial administration of justice. For instance, our police-court, over which a European magistrate presides, has been and is so much corrupted, that coloured men despair of ever obtaining justice in it; whilst in its present state, presided over by a military man holding the responsible position of magistrate, without any legal training, and of whose total incompetency for the office there is not a shadow of doubt.

In our Supreme Court we should have failed in obtaining justice, were it not for the noble institution of trial by jury, which is a blessed privilege in Great Britain and her colonies. To say nothing of justice, perverted and arbitrary powers assumed for many years past, I would only tell you that not very long ago, an individual who had been sentenced from the bench of his worship the magistrate of the police-court (for theft) to imprisonment for six months' hard labour, appealed to the Supreme Court, and was there declared innocent of the charge by the verdict of jurors. I conclude, Mr. Editor, with the wish and hope that the ears of the good people of Great Britain may no longer be shut to our cries, and that they, examining into our real conditions and wants, will give to us better men to administer to us.—Yours, &c.,", 'last_edit_date': '1869-06-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1869#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.619, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "Anecdotes of African Mail Steamers—Power of Mr. Rainy's Name", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Surely the directors of the African Royal Mail Steamship Company, to which the Biafra belongs, cannot be cognisant of the harsh treatment the colored people always experienced from some of the officers. Purser Ditchfield is especially one of these. He forgot himself so far the other day as to make an attempt to use his fist on a colored gentleman, a chief-cabin passenger, but the name of Mr. Rainy soon drove him to his shell. The circumstances are truthfully as follows: Mr. Ditchfield contended that the luggage of this chief-cabin passenger was more than allowed in the scale governing chief-cabin passengers, and then proceeded to tax the gentleman as per original bill herewith enclosed, and which you will please publish, should you deem it necessary, for the information of your readers.', 'last_edit_date': '1869-02-10', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_03_1869#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.622, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE "PASSENGER QUESTION" IN WEST AFRICAN STEAMERS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In our last number we felt it to be our duty to make some remarks upon the alleged inhuman treatment of Kroomen returning home from the Oil Rivers, &c., by the West African steamers. We then expressed our readiness to insert any explanations that might be addressed to us on the subject. We have not hitherto received any. The two Steamship Companies, who have rendered immense service to the West African merchants and traders, and consequently to the cultivators in Africa, by the greatly increased demand for their produce, consequent on the growing facilities which those Companies have afforded for shipping it to European ports, more especially Liverpool, do now virtually enjoy a monopoly of the carrying and passenger trade between England and West Africa. Some efforts have from time to time been made to break down that monopoly, which, however, proved to be far too strong for the new adventurers. Nor do we for ourselves deprecate in any way the continuance of that monopoly, the right to which we think these Companies have fairly earned, provided always that it does not grossly abuse its power. And this we are now compelled to say it does in the matter of accommodation—or rather, of what is represented to us as the total lack of all decent accommodation or treatment for and of second-class passengers between Liverpool and the West Coast ports. If these representations be correct, nothing can be more scandalously bad.
**115**', 'last_edit_date': '1882-10-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_10_1882#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.643, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Royal Mail Steamship Company', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We cannot in any way vouch for the truth of the following, which appeared lately in a Sierra Leone paper, relative to the steamship Norway, of this Company, when at that port on the 1st (3rd) October, but past experience only too fully justifies us in believing it, in default of satisfactory evidence to the contrary. The paragraph is as follows: "Several respectable persons who had occasion to visit this steamer while she lay in harbour, have informed us that they witnessed acts of gross brutality towards some coloured persons committed by the subordinate officers of the Norway, such as kicking people in the face, knocking them about, &c., &c. We are sorry to have to record that, judging by the statements of some gentlemen who saw what they relate, it would seem that the people on board this Norway are determined that the old Company shall not have any customers. There is more grumbling now than ever against their smaller steamers, and the general feeling of dissatisfaction will lead sooner or later to a state of things which must result in serious loss to this mercantile company, which, after all, has in its day been very useful to Africa. No warnings (be the spirit in which they are conceived ever so friendly, be the manner in which they are expressed ever so earnest) seem to be heeded. It is apparently a case of _Quem Deus._ We do not want to see this old Company go to ruin, notwithstanding our just causes of complaint against it; and we therefore earnestly advise the shareholders to call their executive to a sharp account about these matters. We tell them plainly that nothing short of this can save them from an eventual catastrophe!—Ed. A. T.', 'last_edit_date': '1869-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1869#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.633, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ARE NOT POOR AFRICAN LIVES VALUABLE?', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—You cannot imagine how careless some of the steamship captains—Captain Davies, commander of the African Steamship Company’s Steamer Soudan, among others—are, of the lives of Africans. I will mention a case or two lately.

On the 10th of April last, while Captain Davies was leaving Fernando Po Harbour, a Krooman was killed by the propeller of the ship. Being too hasty, Captain Davies did not wait to have the ship’s boat hauled up and properly made fast before the steamer started, as it is the custom with other captains generally to do. He started the ship all at once, the hook of the boat gave way, while this poor man was inside the boat, and he was killed by the propeller of the ship, and his blood overflowed the surface of the water. Would Captain Davies have to give an account for such an act as this, if a man had been thus killed in the river at Liverpool?

Again, when he was about to leave the Harbour of Gaboon on the 13th of July, for the Leeward Coast, without giving any sign of departure, he all at once started the Soudan, and a poor native man, inside his canoe, belonging to this country, was so scalded that he is now on the verge of death.

I hope you will think it worth while to notice this criminal carelessness of Captain Davies, and that your doing so will lead to such a change as will prevent the lives of poor Africans being so recklessly sacrificed.', 'last_edit_date': '1871-07-29', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1871#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.625, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE POSITION OF THE NEGRO IN AMERICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A similar case occurred on Long Island, within thirty miles of New York, a few months ago, and there again the coloured parents failed to obtain satisfaction or redress. Fred Douglass, who as stated above has just sailed for Hayti as United States Minister, and has already held the office of U.S. Marshal of the District of Columbia, was refused accommodation by all of the leading hotels on his arrival at Jacksonville, Florida, the other day. I should add that the hotels in question are all owned and "run" by New York managers for the exclusive benefit and use of northern guests. In Brooklyn, "the city of churches," it is impossible for a coloured citizen, no matter how great his office, wealth, and respectability, to obtain in the theatres any other seats than those of the upper gallery. Most of the conventions of the Episcopal, Methodist, Presbyterian, and Baptist churches refuse to admit any coloured ecclesiastic to their deliberations, thus ignoring the divine lesson which was taught to St. Peter when he saw "the sheet let down from heaven by the four corners," and learnt that "God, being no respecter of persons," made no exception in the case of black sheep. In several of my previous letters to the _Examiner & Times_, I have had occasion to refer to the laws which exist in many States of the Union rendering mixed marriages between blacks and whites a penal offence punishable by imprisonment with hard labour, the offence being designated by the word miscegenation. In Boston, that "hub of the universe" around which the civilised world is supposed to revolve, the retail traders refuse to employ coloured people as clerks, salesmen, and saleswomen, in their shops, simply because they are black. At Ashbury Park, a popular seaside resort on the New Jersey coast, frequented almost exclusively by New Yorkers, and within an hour's ride of their city, the coloured visitors and residents are not permitted to bathe in the ocean at the same time as the whites. President Harrison, far from protesting against this shameful discrimination against the negro race, has done much towards encouraging it, by dismissing all the coloured servants who had rendered service at the White House since the days of Abraham Lincoln. Even poor old Hawkins, the head coachman, who has driven at least eight Presidents to and from the capitol on the day of their inauguration, was turned away, General Harrison refusing to be driven by a "black man." The old coloured "auntie," too, who had been employed in the Presidential kitchen since the time of General Grant, was sent off with a week's wages; and President Harrison recently appointed Lewis Parsons, one of the leaders of the anti-negro movement in the south, to the post of U.S. District Attorney for the State of Alabama. In Chicago last spring all the 800 workmen of Messrs. Kirk's great soap manufactory went on strike because two negroes had been given some menial position about the office, and the firm was consequently obliged to dismiss the negroes. It is but the other day that the powerful "Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers," the head-quarters of which are in this city, issued a notice announcing that no coloured man would be admitted to membership.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-10-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_11_1889#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.632, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "HER MAJESTY'S SHIPS EMPLOYED IN 'ORDINARY WEST AFRICAN SERVICE", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Attention has often been called, in our columns and elsewhere, to the comparative greater mortality and sickness on board Her Majesty's ships employed on the West Coast of Africa, and that on board well-appointed merchant vessels employed there in trading operations. This was one of the subjects briefly alluded to during the mercantile interview with Earl Kimberley in May last. There can be no doubt of the great mortality and sickness being the result of an improper selection of ships, as we showed a few years ago, when the yellow fever committed heavy ravages on board one or two of them at Sierra Leone. What can be expected in a tropical climate on board such ships as below described by one of the daily press correspondents on the Gold Coast: "If one has only a certain distance to go, and one wishes to be as long a time as possible over it, it would be difficult, if not impossible, to select a vessel better fitted for the purpose than Her Majesty's ship Bittern. The slowest auxiliary screw collier that drops down the Tyne could walk round Her Majesty's ship Bittern, and she sails as badly as she steams. With their rolling propensities, the Bittern class are not comfortable ships to be in. The accommodation for the crew is scanty and ill-ventilated. The officers' cabins are little better than dog-kennels; the captain's state-room is a black-hole. Such is the Bittern." Is it not time that there should be some new reform in the administration of the Navy, by which a real and effective, and no longer a mock responsibility should attach to the authorities, whoever they may be, who order the dispatch of unsuitable vessels to tropical and other trying climates, to the shameful risk of the lives and health of officers and men. Such ships as the Bittern, as above described, are a disgrace to Great Britain, and the sooner they are got rid of from the Navy the better, whatever the cost of the reform by which this may be accomplished.—*Ed. A.T.*', 'last_edit_date': '1874-01-29', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_01_1874#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.642, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "Massacre of Fifteen of the Crew of Her Majesty's Ship Penguin", 'section_title': '', 'content': "We lament having to record the massacre of an officer, twelve seamen, and two marines of Her Majesty's ship Penguin, 5, screw gun vessel, Lieut. J. G. G. M'Hardy, employed in the suppression of the slave-trade on the eastern coast of Africa.

hh: Historical skepticism about African races' capacities highlights the need for unbiased research into their anatomical and intellectual capabilities, as previous studies may have been incomplete or biased, potentially underestimating their potential for development and economic activity.
result: The observations from the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively underscore the historical skepticism about African races' capacities and the pressing need for unbiased research into their anatomical and intellectual capabilities. The textbook highlights the efforts of West African intellectuals like James Africanus Horton and Edward Wilmot Blyden, who actively refuted racist ideas and argued against the notion of inherent racial inferiority. Horton emphasized that differences in civilization stages were due to external circumstances rather than racial inferiority, advocating for the potential of Africans to contribute significantly to global civilization. This aligns with the claim's call for unbiased research, as Horton and Blyden's work sought to challenge and correct biased perceptions. The textbook also discusses the psychological impact of pseudo-scientific racist theories, which created a sense of inferiority among some Africans, further supporting the need for objective research. However, it does not explicitly address anatomical studies, focusing instead on intellectual and cultural capabilities. In contrast, The African Times articles highlight the biased nature of previous studies, such as Dr. Hunt's work, which relied on craniological measurements from uncivilized tribes to assert the inferiority of the negro race, ignoring the existence of civilized and Christianized negro communities. The articles call for a corresponding examination of the physiology of the civilized negro race, suggesting that previous research may have been incomplete or biased. They also discuss Africa's potential for economic development, emphasizing the continent's natural resources and the capabilities of its people when given opportunities for education and self-governance. This supports the claim that historical skepticism may have underestimated Africa's potential for development and economic activity. Both sources reflect a broader discourse on the racial inferiority debate, indicating that the question of racial capacities remains open and contentious, which aligns with the claim's call for unbiased research.

[{'id': 480, 'article_title': 'THE TIMES ON AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'THE TIMES ON AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-19', 'issue_date': '23_11_1864', 'content': 'In editorial comments on Earl Russell's speech at Aberdeen, the *Times* says:—

"There could hardly be a more crucial test of a sanguine belief in human destiny than a confidence in the civilization of Africa. From time immemorial that vast continent has been the darkest spot in the habitable world, for neither the influence of Egypt on the East, nor that of the Roman province on the North, penetrated far into the interior. We have no reason to suppose that Africa was ever a happier country than it is now, and what it is now—how distracted with incessant wars, how desolated by famines and pestilences, how full of cruelty—may be learnt from the pages of recent travellers. The elevation of Africa to the level, we will not say of Europe or America, but of Asia, would be no restoration, but the extrication, as it were, of a new tract from the great deep. *It has been predicted, indeed, but only as communication with some neighbouring planet might be predicted.* At the same time it must be owned that to despair of improving the lot of Africa is to despair of making one community of the whole human race, even for commercial purposes. Now, if we are to build castles in the air at all, we must not stop short of this ideal. What appears certain is, that the march of civilization cannot be carried much further without overspreading Africa. Whether the African races will develop capacities the very germs of which physiologists doubt their possessing, or whether they will fill a subordinate place in a society yet to be organised, Lord Russell himself forbears to inquire, and we shall not venture to go beyond him.'}, {'id': 660, 'article_title': 'THE ALLEGED ESSENTIAL INFERIORITY OF THE NEGRO.', 'full_section_title': 'THE ALLEGED ESSENTIAL INFERIORITY OF THE NEGRO.', 'last_edit_date': '06-28-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_07_1865#article-20', 'issue_date': '22_07_1865', 'content': 'Sir,—In Dr. Hunt's notorious brochure "On the Negro's Place in Nature" (Trübner & Co., 1863), he brings forward a large number of craniological measurements and physiological details from the works of M. Pruner, of Egypt, in proof of the essential inferiority of the negro race to the European. In adopting this plausible line of argument, he is open to the objection of one-sidedness, seeing that all Pruner Bey's data are derived from an anatomical investigation of Nubian and Soudanese, consequently of barbarous and uncivilised human subjects. Dr. Hunt absolutely ignores the existence of every civilised and Christianised negro community in the world when he speaks of anatomical, craniological, and osteological matters. Deriving his data from an investigation of the anatomy of barbarous tribes, he places the negro facial angle at from 70 degs. to 75 degs., declares the weight of the brain and the mean measurement of the surface of the cranium to be much less than those of Aryans, and asserts that the negro brain bears a great resemblance to a European female or child's brain, thus in limine consigning the whole black race to irredeemable and absolute inferiority. If similar investigations were confined to certain uncivilised and barbarous Indo-European tribes, or portions thereof, similar conclusions might be arrived at.

But in the meantime, the black race is suffering from imputations which are believed to be groundless and unfounded. Mr. Edward Blyden, of Monrovia, in the pamphlet* which he published in that town in 1857, declares that in geographies, or books on ethnography, the heads given as representing the normal African are those of slaves, while those representative of the Caucasian race are either the heads of philosophers or of very beautiful females. They give the highest type of the European and the lowest type of the negro. Dr. Hunt and his friends similarly draw their facts from degraded tribes of negroes, and then palm them off upon society as proofs of the irredeemable character of the whole race.

I have troubled you with these remarks, Mr. Editor, in the hope of inducing some of your readers on the West Coast of Africa, or elsewhere, to correspond with me on this interesting subject. I should feel deeply indebted to any physician, surgeon, or other accurate observer, if he would send me facts as to the facial angle, craniological development, cranial capacity, and general osteological structure of civilised negroes. Photographs of distinguished negroes, from which the gradual approximation to the Caucasian race in brain-development, and the absence of prognathism, might be gathered, would also be acceptable, as well as facts in proof of the capacity of the negro for self-government.'}, {'id': 660, 'article_title': 'THE ALLEGED ESSENTIAL INFERIORITY OF THE NEGRO.', 'full_section_title': 'THE ALLEGED ESSENTIAL INFERIORITY OF THE NEGRO.', 'last_edit_date': '06-28-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_07_1865#article-20', 'issue_date': '22_07_1865', 'content': "In conclusion, allow me to say that M. Pruner Bey's minute investigation into the anatomy of the Nubian and Soudanese blacks imperatively calls for a corresponding examination of the physiology of the civilised negro race. This latter field of research has, so far at least as my knowledge extends, never been efficiently entered, and I cannot but think would produce results far different to those exhibited during the last two or three years before the British Association and the Anthropological Society.

I am, Sir, your obedient servant,  
**JAMES FOX WILSON.**"}, {'id': 3881, 'article_title': 'WEST COAST RAILROADS', 'full_section_title': 'WEST COAST RAILROADS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1879#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_11_1879', 'content': 'The more our mind dwells on the various efforts now under consideration, or actually being made, for the opening up of Africa to civilization and commerce, the more ardent become our desires for the construction of railways in and from the British possessions on the West Coast. With the increase of desires comes also the determination not to leave any effort untried to accomplish that great object. We have not taken the matter up lightly, or in ignorance of the many obstacles in our path, whether they be such as seem to be inseparable from the administration of Crown colonies, the ignorant inertia of the population more immediately to be benefited, or the interested apathy or opposition of Europeans, who prefer, to use their own words, "to let things go on as they are," because they imagine that with increased development and life, there will be more than a relative increase of commercial competition. The objects we have in view, the results at which we aim, are too widely beneficial on the one hand and too sacred on the other, for us to allow such impediments, on which we had fully calculated, to damp our energies or cause us to intermit our exertions. We know that populations steeped in heathen ignorance and sunk morally in the lowest depths of evil, where all the highest principles of humanity are violated, and the most debasing influences prevail and riot unrestrained, cannot be effectually reached by the piercing light of truth, without those facilities of access which railways only can furnish. The Gospel of the coming kingdom of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ must be preached "as a witness" to all nations; and we feel that by the construction of the railways we have projected, and their extension, this one great object will be facilitated, in so far as that portion of Africa is concerned in and through which their course will lie. But as it is contrary to all precedent to imagine that we could give birth by the enunciation of such views and objects to any such enthusiasm as would help materially in the execution of our plans, we must of necessity appeal to those material interests which move the mainsprings of human action, and influence both governments and individuals. We have been, and shall, we doubt not, again be told, that the subjugation of evil, and the ennobling of debased humanity are very well in their way; but that to loosen the purse-strings of Government or capitalists, we must be able to show the certainty of results that are more generally appreciated and desired. Will the proposed railways lead to such development of resources as shall ensure that "they shall pay"? In view of what has been effected in other countries by such constructions, a really paternal Government would not hesitate a moment in determining to apply any available resources and powers it might possess to endow the lands over which it holds sway with such approved agencies in the creation of public and private wealth. It is becoming very much the fashion to laud and praise uncontrolled Imperialism as the great fountain of good to peoples. The administration of Crown colonies is an uncontrolled Imperialism. We thirst to behold the fertilizing streams of this much-lauded fountain flowing through and from our West African settlements and colonies, where, if anywhere on earth, there would be no impediments to their course. We long to see Imperialism at work there in a wise and bold encouragement of efforts for the development of material resources, on which the wealth and well-being of subjects depend. We see Imperialism active in subjugation; let us have a view of it working with beneficent regard to the wants and necessities of subjects who, through poverty and ignorance, are incapable of helping themselves in the midst of an abounding natural wealth. There is a rich field for its exertions in this direction within the Gold Coast territories. It will not do to tell us the people are naturally lazy, have very few wants, and have not, therefore, any incentives to exertion, such as could alone lead to the increased production and development of, at present, unutilized resources, as would recuperate the Exchequer for even the small outlay which is needed to convert our projects into realities. We deny it; and we appeal to facts in complete justification of our denial. We heard the same falsehood when it was proposed that there should be steam communication with the West Coast by the ships of one company alone every fortnight, instead of once a month; it thundered in our ears anew when another steamship company was about to enter the field, and communication once a week was established. We heard it some twelve or fourteen years ago, when the revenues of the British possessions on the Gold Coast amounted to only seven thousand pounds a year; and those of the Dutch possessions, intermixed with the British, were so far from paying the expenses of their government, that this entailed on the Netherlands a loss of some ten or twelve thousand pounds a year. Those possessions, which have since come entirely under British administration by the retirement of the Dutch, yield now a revenue of one hundred thousand pounds a year; notwithstanding errors that have enriched the French possession, Assinee, at the expense of the Gold Coast Treasury, and although no appreciable portion of the revenue has been employed for improving communications, and thus facilitating the operations of trade and commerce. These are undeniable facts. Are we not justified in appealing to them in support of our denial of the supposed invincible laziness, the paucity, or rather inelastic paucity, of wants, and the absence of incentives to exertion? And, let it be remembered, there has not been any internal extension of the area of production. There has been a small coast extension—only a very small one—but there has not been any internal extension, which could only be accomplished by the opening of roads, and the substitution of some other means for the conveyance of goods and produce to and from the coast for that of human heads, on which alone the tens of thousands of tons of produce and goods per annum have been and still are carried. If the greater freedom of action given to the people by the whole coast line being under one sole jurisdiction, and by the proclamation which enfranchised all domestic slaves who desired their freedom, while it prohibited any further transfer or sale of slaves or taking of pawns, has led to such a marvellous increase of revenue, surely it may be inferred that the people are not ineradicably idle, that they are capable of increased wants, that there are some motives or incentives which rouse them to action, and that by doubling the zone of production by the facilities which railways will offer for the transport of produce to the coast from districts too distant for conveyance on human heads, something like a hundred per cent. increase in exports, imports, and revenue will, within a few years, be attained. The country is one of marvellous resources, which never can be utilized, except in fractions, until the means for transport and more rapid, easy, and cheap communication are provided. We do not hesitate to say that there is not another European State—not even the so-styled lethargic Spain and Portugal—that would placidly fold its administrative arms in presence of so vast an amount of undeveloped wealth at so short a distance from its shores as the Gold Coast is from England, and fail to welcome and tender the willing hand of judicious assistance such as its Treasury might be able to afford to enterprise seeking to pronounce the "open sesame," by the construction of suitable railways, that would place that wealth at its disposal and the disposal of its subjects. The manufacturing industries of Great Britain are calling for new markets, to take the place for their productions of old ones that are irrecoverably lost; but their great capitalists do not yet seem to comprehend the new order of things that has arisen for this country of Great Britain. [{'document_title': "DR. HORTON'S BOOK.", 'section_title': '', 'content': "Both Africa and Europe are indebted to Dr. Horton for this work. The author is not a man who has taken a run down the West Coast and back again in a mail steamer, and then written a book chiefly valuable as an evidence of the extent to which the boasted European intellect, when it has a wrong bias, can be gulled as to facts, and be made worthless as regards conclusions. One of the two only of native Africans who have been educated for Government Medical Service, Dr. Horton, as a Staff Assistant Surgeon, has passed eight years at the different British settlements on the West Coast. We feel, then, when we take up his book that he ought to know what he is writing about; and, on perusing it, find that he not only ought to know, but does know. It is not to be inferred from this that we agree with all his reasonings, admit all his conclusions, and coincide with all his views. In our position as regards West Africa we think it necessary to state this at once, that we may not be misunderstood. But we say unhesitatingly that the book is a valuable one—is a book that is very much wanted—that it is calculated to remove many misconceptions as regards the people and countries of which it treats—that it ought to do much toward clearing away the thick haze of prejudice in which the West Coast countries have been shrouded—and that it must, we think, convince every unprejudiced reader that those people and countries have a future of great importance to the civilised world, and of deep soul-stirring interest to the Christian, who is praying, hoping, teaching, and striving for the extension of the great Redeemer's kingdom.

The earlier portion of the volume is devoted to an *exposé* of the gross errors and misstatements and absurd reasonings that have been in vogue relative to the West African races and the countries they inhabit. Really, Dr. Hunt knows nothing of Africa and the Africans, and except that he is determined to hold on to his standard, the Congo, and, like the wily horse, determine not to know the truth. I can assure him that I have seen men in Africa, and not a few, taller men than any Yorkshire man I have ever come across, some of whom have been regarded as unproportionately tall. What will he say of the tall Sonninkees and Marabouts of Bathurst? What will he say of the gigantic Awoonas in the Slave Coast? As regards the weight of the skeleton, I deny its being heavier in many instances, whilst it might be in others, just as the skeleton of a navy in England is far heavier than the skeleton of a philosopher like Dr. Hunt. The negro chest, he says, is laterally compressed; but for the dysentery, I should like him to visit the interior of the Gold Coast, and examine some of those Cabocceers there, and then let him say whether he has seen better-developed chests in any part of the world.

I find that I should be trespassing too much on your valuable columns were I to attempt to criticise all the statements of Dr. Hunt, and with your permission, I shall endeavour to make a few remarks on the leading points.

Some writers have said that great improvement has taken place in the intellect of the negro by education. Dr. Hunt said such is not the fact. M. Quatrefages, with M. HORTON'S BOOK.", 'section_title': '', 'content': "Falsehoods and aberrations of intellect brought thus unitedly before us, and demolished by real scientific facts; and a clear and lucid reasoning upon them in defence and favour of his long-maligned and deeply-injured race, that establishes the truth, for which we have always contended, that the present indisputable mental superiority of the civilised European over the uncivilised African is merely one of degree, not one of kind—the result of circumstances, and not of natural diversity. This work by a native African ought to do much to rehabilitate in European estimation the race to which he belongs. It shows nice powers of observation—great diligence—a clear appreciation of facts, and a mental daring that does not shrink from the great problems of the future of the various divisions of his race, on which the light of Christian civilisation is only now beginning to shine, and who are for the most part placed under circumstances most unfavourable to its increase. After having vindicated the Africans from the stigma of natural inferiority endeavoured to be fixed upon them by anthropologists and others, the author passes in interesting and instructive review the republic of Liberia, the various British settlements from the River Gambia to Lagos inclusive, and the native races beyond in Dahomey, the Yoruba country, the Niger, and Oil River countries. Showing us their actual condition, and exposing many errors of administration which are opposed to material development and social advancement, he views the whole in connexion with the resolutions of the late House of Commons Committee, 1865, recommending the preparing of the several people for self-government. He shows the great changes that must be induced and fostered to make such self-government possible, safe, or beneficial. Though he has evidently a deep and, we believe, a just faith in his race, he does not shut his eyes to any of the disadvantages of their actual position and the difficulties in the way of their progress toward Christianity, civilisation, and wealth. The book ought to be read and studied by all educated Africans, and we should like to see it have a large circulation in England, as we consider it calculated to arouse sympathies for Africa where they have never yet been felt, and to give them a vigorous impulse where they do already exist. Our space will not allow more at present, but we shall from time to time quote from and comment upon its contents. We cannot say it is perfect in style, but the faults are very venial ones, and such as we have no doubt an increased practice in writing will cause to disappear from those future works on this interesting subject of the West African Countries and Peoples which we hope to see from this author's pen. of Dr. Hunt, which detract greatly from their value, and sully his position as a man of learning. He sneers, of course, at the just and valid reasonings of the ethnologists, Prichard, Pollas, Lacépède, Hunt, Doornik, and Link, that the European, or white race, originated from the black, or negro races, or the doctrine of the evolution of the white varieties in the black races of men.', 'last_edit_date': '1866-04-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_04_1866#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.616, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SURGEONS FOR THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'While we in England have felt it our duty to urge the claims of properly-qualified surgeons, natives of Africa, to appointments as assistant surgeons on the African Coast, the same subject has been violently agitating our friends on the Gold Coast. This has raised—and considering the strong expressions used in the report, we must say we think not without full and sufficient causes—a storm of indignation against those who have taken so unfavourable a view of a measure that we ourselves feel to be of vital importance in the work of African advancement and regeneration. We give insertion to the following as a sample of what we are now receiving on this subject. It cannot be a matter of surprise that educated men, wholly or partially of African blood, should come forward strongly to assert and vindicate their claims to a fair footing on the great human stage, when they learn at the same time the contents of a report so unfavourable to them as that we have alluded to, and of the efforts of the Anthropological Society, and others here, to revive, as regards the Africans, the infidel Monboddo theory, that they have gradually risen from the ape species. We who have no African blood in our veins can afford to treat all such deductions from the results of so-called scientific research with the contempt it deserves, merely replying with the inspired writer, "God, who hath made of one blood all nations of men to dwell on the face of the earth." I feel identified with the coloured race by my five years' imprisonment in Missouri, on account of my love of the slave, and by my six years' residence in West Africa, where I laboured hard and suffered much for them; and should probably have remained, but for the ill-health of my family—wife and child. We had buried our first-born there, a little boy of six years.

But poor Africa—what can be done for her? I rejoice in the success of Dr. Livingston, and of every other explorer and labourer in Africa; but much more need to be and can be done for her. 1. She needs missionaries and teachers, but these alone will not do the work needed. Accompanying them should be (2) farmers and mechanics, who can teach them civilization, for both must go together—civilization and Christianity: either without the other will fail; but both united will, with God's blessing, lift her up, and soon give her a place among the nations.

She has natural resources abundant. 1. The people are capable of being educated in the arts and sciences, in which they make rapid proficiency when an opportunity is provided. In managing business, mercantile or other, they manifest an ability equal to the whites. The richest men in Sierra Leone are negroes who were taken out of the slave ship. They make very efficient preachers, teachers, mechanics, farmers, &c., when instructed.

2. The country is rich—very productive in many things needful for commerce and home consumption. Rice, Indian corn, and some smaller grains, suited to exportation, can be produced to any extent. Ginger, pepper, arrowroot, can be supplied to meet the wants of the world. Coffee and cotton of fine quality grow wild abundantly, and can be cultivated to any extent to supply Manchester and every cotton factory in Christendom. There only needs to do this to start it all along the Western Coast, and make a market for them, and the natives will go to producing them. They will work at what they can make the most money by. Africa is by far the best and most natural coffee and cotton country in the world, and, I will add, sugar-cane also. These articles are spontaneous products of the soil. Coffee is a forest tree, from twenty to seventy-five feet high, as I saw myself, and is cultivated with great care. Cotton grows to quite a bush, from six to ten feet high, and the same bush bears a crop every year; and sugar-cane, when once planted, will shoot up and make new crops as often as cut down. These things I have seen.

3. And her minerals are rich and abundant. Gold and iron ore, the purest in the world, is very abundant in many parts. Copper, zinc, lead, &c., have been discovered, how abundant we know not. Liberia has been a black republic for forty years; Sierra Leone has been a negro colony for a century; and it cannot be denied that each of these communities has made very gratifying progress. Yet, upon Dr. Blyden's own showing, that progress has been but partial, he still has to complain of his countrymen's imitativeness and lack of backbone. The responsibility for this, undoubtedly, rests to some extent upon the unsuitable character of the education which the civilized negroes have received; but it is more to the purpose to remember that three generations is a very brief period in the development of a pagan people. How slow the work of civilization in Liberia has been may be seen from the fact that, whereas there are some twenty thousand Christian negroes in the republic, there are more than a million who are pagans. And now we inevitably come to the primary question of all: whether or not the presumed racial inferiority of the negro is proved. Dr. Blyden pleads eloquently for his fellows, and triumphantly asks: How could an inferior race have produced Toussaint L'Ouverture? The question is not unnatural, but it is far from logical. The matter, as it fashions itself to us, is, and is likely to remain for a long time to come, an open one. The negro has, as yet, enjoyed no sufficient opportunity of proving either his mental equality with or his inferiority to the white. The experience of Sierra Leone and Liberia, so far as it has gone, has been in his favour; what we know of his moral history in that other black republic, Hayti, and in the United States, is at the best negative. As time goes on, the question, which is far more momentous than would appear to the unthinking, will settle itself. Emigration from America to Liberia, under the auspices of the American Colonization Society, is proceeding satisfactorily; and Dr. Blyden states that 200,000 negroes in the United States are prepared to return to the land of their fathers. But colonization by private effort is, at the best, exceedingly slow; and in this instance it is perhaps well that it is so, since the gradual settlement of Liberia is far more likely to provide material for a strong and healthy State than a hasty rush would be. Social reformers for many a year to come will watch the experiment, as they have watched it in the past, with keen interest. The chief danger lies, as Dr. Blyden constantly points out, in the tendency to Europeanize the negro—to supersede customs and practices which are useful and often necessary in Africa by customs utterly out of place there. The ill-directed zeal of some of the less reflective missionaries has, no doubt, been to blame for some of this; but there is, we fancy, very little to complain of upon this head now. The possibility of such a thing had never yet reached my brain. At last, in colloquy with an old friend upon the Coast, the idea started up, and after due discussion, we adopted it. I speak of morals. In intellect the black race is palpably superior, and it is fast advancing in the path of civilization."—Vol. II., p. 73. As the author's almost hatred of Africans is everywhere apparent, this, which would, no doubt, have been "worn-out declamation" from us, may possibly be considered worthy of credit.

The F.R.G.S. carries about with him everywhere "a consul," as closely attached to and as inseparable from him as were the Siamese twins to and from each other, so that we may be excused if we fail at times to distinguish between them. We thank them or him for the testimony "that the land of West Africa might be rendered not more unhealthy than the East or the West Indies," but we do not at all agree with him that even now "it is deadly—a Golgotha—a Jehannum"—except to those who conspire against themselves to make it so to them. The changes proposed with a most admirable aplomb, here, there, and everywhere, are few, if any, of them new to us, and our readers will recognise many that have been indicated in our pages. We must refer them to the work itself, which they will find in many parts very amusing. The following antipodes of our author describes a person such as we have not unfrequently met with in our own peregrinations: "At Accra we left our Spaniard. He was a gentleman fond of his bed and also of his Madeiran wicker-work armchair. He read a little; but when excited, which was rare, he would declaim loudly against the practice of 'lecture,' as worthless touching the main enjoyments of human life—eating, drinking, visiting friends, and attending the theatre. According to him, the summum bonum of human life was to lie upon his back smoking cigarettes and looking at the moon or at all the stars. He once, but only once, gathered energy to sermon me upon the subject of over curiosity. I had remarked that the thermometer stood unusually high. JOSEPH THOMSON ON EUROPEAN INTERCOURSE WITH AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Having glanced at African exploration during the past 400 years, the lecturer proceeded to inquire what had been the net outcome of direct and indirect efforts and sacrifices and intercourse between the European and the African. He knew that the impression they had acquired from various sources was that the beneficent results were enormous; but he had been enabled to see for himself the nature of those results and to draw his own conclusions, and he appeared before them to put a pin into the beautiful iridescent bubble which they had blown for themselves with the materials supplied by the ignorant, the interested, the colour-blind, and the hopelessly biassed. Taking a bird's-eye view of the whole situation in time and space, so that each factor might assume its proper relative position and proportion, he unhesitatingly affirmed in the plainest language that so far their intercourse with African races, instead of being a blessing, had been little better than an unmitigated curse to them. Our purpose was to see what was said of Africa, the land we live in. Imagine our chagrin on finding the existence of that by no means petty continent quietly but totally ignored. Much space was, of course, accorded to the states of Europe, and the rest of the volume had reference to states not in Europe; but among these was not Africa. America, Asia, and Australia each receive a fair measure of attention, but this vast African land—although it occupies a fourth of the area of the habitable earth—although its history is older than that of any part of Europe, and its population is a ninth part of mankind—does not even come within the category of outside states—has no recognised standing—remains still a blank on the muster roll of nations. Why should this be? Why should Africa be, even in this latest age, so much a myth—so utterly obscure and unimportant—that it can be thus passed by? In old times, as far back as history reaches, the northern shores of this continent were the seats of empires that dominated the world, but now the sceptre is no longer held, the name evokes no sentiment but pity; the gloom of mystery and ignorance invests the land, and the great current of civilization as it sweeps with hastening impulse round the world, would never leave a trace upon its shores, were not stray eddies sometimes caught and kept by a few points like these.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.618, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'REVIEW', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Stanford's book fully justifies the title he has given to it. It is indeed a compendium. It places before us in brief but luminous sketches, and with the aid of sixteen admirable maps and some seventy illustrations, all that is publicly known about Africa and its peoples—their specific peculiarities, character, manners, customs, and condition, physical and moral; with enumeration of its varied products, its trade and commerce. It is an admirable volume for all who desire general information respecting that great continent, into the dense darkness of which the light of civilization and Christianity has begun to penetrate, through the devoted exertions of missionaries and scientific explorers. Africa does not present us with any very pleasing pictures. They are all of barbarism, and for the most part barbarism of the lowest and most disgusting type, and yet such as awakes and impels to active exertion the warmest sympathies and desires of the Christian and philanthropist. Such books as this of Mr. Stanford's are particularly valuable in view of the extremely limited degree of information respecting Africa possessed even by the majority of well-educated people in England. So many active agencies are now at work in and for Africa that some more intimate knowledge of it must be desired; while yet the labour of wading through long and dreary books of African travel, with their sadly monotonous succession of pictures of sparsely-inhabited countries, and of ignorance, suffering, cruelty, and moral degradation everywhere, deters most people from seeking it in their pages. This "Compendium" meets such desires, and gets rid of such difficulties, offering as a prize to be gained by a few leisure hours' reading all that it is essential well-educated people should know of this great continent. From the foregoing the reflective mind will at once perceive that the race which descended to Africa were subject to several vicissitudes, which had a most depressing effect on them, and which deprived them of that brilliancy which is shown by the other races, but who, after a change of their religion and the cultivation of their minds, endeavour to claim their position in the world's history. This displeases some of the Japhetic race, especially those residing in Africa, and they consequently use all their endeavours to crush them.

It can now be seen that, believing in the genuineness and authenticity of the most holy and most ancient Book, man, or the race which inhabits this globe, had one origin; that they were dark in colour, if not black; and that, having first peopled the track of land eastward of the Mediterranean, from their descendants, the Ethiopian, Caucasian, and Mongolian races proceeded.

All these go to account for their conformation.

In every part of Africa we occasionally meet with a perfectly white child, the offspring of perfectly black parents; these are known by the name of albino. Here is a freak of nature by which they are superlatively white, with the dermal cells perfectly destitute of those pigment matters found even amongst Europeans. If a great many of these albinoes were formed into a town, and propagation encouraged, a new race of people would be formed, which, but for the climate and domestic habits, would be as white as a Greenlander.

We suppose that of the early inhabitants of this globe one family, passing through the Isthmus of Suez, entered into Africa, another branch taking quite an opposite direction, and proceeding to the temperate zone, gave origin to a different and distinct race of men, who adapted themselves to the climates they inhabited, changing their tropical habits for others suitable to the climatorial influence of the temperate and polar zones; and thus, after the lapse of ages, forming the great Caucasian race. hh: European colonial perspectives often depicted African societies as barbaric and in need of moral guidance, while overlooking their cultural complexities and the strategic caution these societies exercised in interactions with foreigners.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that European colonial perspectives often depicted African societies as barbaric and in need of moral guidance, while overlooking their cultural complexities and strategic caution. The textbook highlights the paternalistic attitude of Europeans, who viewed African societies as lacking culture and history, as evidenced by statements from European historians like A. P. Newton and Sir Reginald Coupland. This perspective, rooted in racism and cultural chauvinism, led to the dismissal of African art, music, and traditions, framing the European presence as a civilizing mission. The colonial narrative, as seen in the mandates system and the rhetoric of the League of Nations, portrayed colonial efforts as a responsibility of advanced nations to tutor supposedly childlike African peoples. In contrast, the textbook emphasizes the strategic caution and resilience of African societies, noting their varied responses to European invasion based on social cohesion and political organization, challenging the simplistic view of African societies as uniformly barbaric. Similarly, The African Times articles describe Africa as a land of chaos and barbarism, emphasizing the need for Christian civilization and European intervention. In a milieu of cultural symbiosis, Africans contributed almost as much to the rest of the society as they accepted from it. Of course, the more they needed and the less they found, the more they became creative as the patois speech pattern of the previously French eastern Caribbean islands and the papiamento of the previously Dutch Antilles reveal. The political and economic reconstruction that followed the Civil War in the USA accompanied a movement of legal discrimination and social and economic exclusion of the non-white sector, characterized by segregated institutions, lynchings, and overtly racist societies and organ› izations, which combined until the middle of the twentieth century.$^{54}$ The general conditions experienced by black Americans then compared with those prevailing today in a more extreme way in South Africa.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.673, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the social field', 'content': "Another highly regrettable social impact of colonialism was the deterior› ation that it caused in the status of the woman in Africa.
